content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

Here is a Julia function that does what you've asked.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md::String)
    lines = split(md, "\n")  # Split the markdown into lines.
    
    question = ""
    answer = ""
    inQuestionSection = false
    inAnswerSection = false
    
    for line in lines
        if startswith(line, "# Question")
            inQuestionSection = true
        elseif inQuestionSection && !startswith(line, "## ")
            question *= strip(line)
        elseif startswith(line, "# Answer")
            inAnswerSection = true
        elseif inAnswerSection && !startswith(line, "## ")
            answer *= strip(line)
        end
    end
    
    return (question, answer)  # Return the question and answer as a tuple.
end
```
This function works by iterating over each line of the markdown. If it encounters a line starting with "# Question", then it switches into the "question" section mode. Likewise, if it encounters a line starting with "# Answer", then it switches into the "answer" section mode.

In both sections, if it encounters a line that does not start with "## ", then it appends this line to whatever section is currently active and strips any leading spaces or newlines from it.

Finally, once all lines have been processed, it returns the question and answer as a tuple. If there are no questions or answers in the markdown, an empty string will be returned for that component of the tuple.
